Question / Statement: An ideal fluid has zero viscosity and is incompressible.
Explanation: Ideal fluids are theoretical fluids with no friction (viscosity) or compressibility.

Question / Statement: Bernoulli’s equation is based on the conservation of mass.
Explanation: It is based on the conservation of Energy.

Question / Statement: A venturimeter is used to measure the discharge of liquid in a pipe.
Explanation: It measures flow rate by measuring pressure difference.

Question / Statement: The pressure at a point in a static fluid acts equally in all directions.
Explanation: This is known as Pascal’s Law.

Question / Statement: Mercury is used in barometers because it has very low density.
Explanation: It is used because of its high density (13.6) and low vapor pressure.

Question / Statement: Laminar flow occurs when the Reynolds number is greater than 4000.
Explanation: Laminar flow occurs when Re < 2000. Re > 4000 is Turbulent.

Question / Statement: A pitot tube measures the static pressure of a fluid.
Explanation: A pitot tube measures Velocity head (Stagnation pressure - Static pressure).

Question / Statement: The viscosity of liquids decreases with an increase in temperature.
Explanation: Heat breaks the cohesive bonds, making liquids flow more easily.

Question / Statement: "Head loss" in pipes is primarily caused by friction.
Explanation: Friction is the major loss; bends/valves are minor losses.

Question / Statement: Specific gravity of pure water is taken as 1.0.
Explanation: It is the standard reference for liquids.

Question / Statement: "Segregation" is the separation of water from the concrete mix.
Explanation: Separation of water is Bleeding. Segregation is separation of aggregates.

Question / Statement: The value "20" in M20 concrete stands for characteristic compressive strength in N/mm².
Explanation: It means 20 MPa strength at 28 days.

Question / Statement: Concrete is very strong in tension but weak in compression.
Explanation: Concrete is strong in compression and weak in tension.

Question / Statement: The Slump Test is used to measure the strength of concrete.
Explanation: It measures Workability (consistency).

Question / Statement: Adding more water to the concrete mix increases its strength.
Explanation: Higher water-cement ratio decreases strength and durability.

Question / Statement: Reinforced Cement Concrete (RCC) weighs approx 2500 kg/m³.
Explanation: Plain Cement Concrete (PCC) is approx 2400 kg/m³.

Question / Statement: Curing of concrete can be stopped after 2 days.
Explanation: Curing requires at least 7 to 28 days for proper hydration.

Question / Statement: "Bulking of sand" occurs due to moisture content.
Explanation: Surface moisture pushes particles apart, increasing volume.

Question / Statement: Calcium Chloride (CaCl₂) is used as a retarder in concrete.
Explanation: It is an Accelerator (speeds up setting). Gypsum is a retarder.

Question / Statement: Vibrators are used to remove entrapped air from concrete.
Explanation: This process is called compaction.

Question / Statement: Hard water forms lather easily with soap.
Explanation: Hard water consumes soap and does not form lather easily.

Question / Statement: The pH value of neutral water is 7.
Explanation: < 7 is acidic, > 7 is alkaline.

Question / Statement: Alum is used in water treatment for disinfection.
Explanation: Alum is used for Coagulation (settling particles). Chlorine is for disinfection.

Question / Statement: Groundwater is generally free from suspended impurities compared to river water.
Explanation: The soil layers act as a natural filter.

Question / Statement: A "Check Valve" allows water to flow in both directions.
Explanation: A check (reflux) valve allows flow in only one direction.

Question / Statement: The Grid Iron system of pipe layout has more dead ends than the Tree system.
Explanation: The Tree (Dead End) system has the most dead ends. Grid Iron allows circulation.

Question / Statement: Residual chlorine in water is harmful and must be zero.
Explanation: A small amount (0.2 mg/l) is required to prevent re-contamination in pipes.

Question / Statement: "Turbidity" refers to the cloudiness of water.
Explanation: It is caused by suspended particles.

Question / Statement: Ferrule is a device used to connect a service pipe to the water main.
Explanation: It is inserted into the main pipe.

Question / Statement: Boiling is the most effective method of sterilization for household water.
Explanation: It kills almost all pathogens.

Question / Statement: Sewage contains about 99.9% solids and 0.1% water.
Explanation: It is the opposite: 99.9% water and 0.1% solids.

Question / Statement: A "Water Seal" in traps prevents foul gases from entering the house.
Explanation: The water barrier stops gases from the sewer line.

Question / Statement: BOD stands for Biochemical Oxygen Demand.
Explanation: It measures the oxygen needed by bacteria to decompose organic matter.

Question / Statement: A "Combined System" carries both sewage and rainwater in the same pipe.
Explanation: "Separate System" uses two different pipes.

Question / Statement: Septic tanks function on the principle of Aerobic decomposition.
Explanation: They function on Anaerobic decomposition (without oxygen).

Question / Statement: A Manhole is usually provided at every bend in a sewer line.
Explanation: To allow access for cleaning and inspection.

Question / Statement: "Sullage" includes waste from toilets.
Explanation: Sullage is liquid waste from kitchen/bath only. Waste from toilets is Sewage/Blackwater.

Question / Statement: The minimum diameter for a public sewer is typically 150mm (15cm).
Explanation: Anything smaller is prone to blockage.

Question / Statement: Fresh sewage is usually acidic in nature.
Explanation: Fresh sewage is Alkaline; it becomes acidic as it becomes stale/septic.

Question / Statement: A "Vent Pipe" is provided to release gases from the septic tank/sewer.
Explanation: It prevents back-pressure and releases foul smells high up.

Question / Statement: "Camber" is the longitudinal slope of the road.
Explanation: Camber is the Transverse (cross) slope for drainage. Longitudinal is Gradient.

Question / Statement: Super-elevation is provided on curves to counteract centrifugal force.
Explanation: It raises the outer edge to keep vehicles on the road.

Question / Statement: Rigid pavements are made of bituminous materials.
Explanation: Rigid pavements are made of Cement Concrete. Flexible are made of Bitumen.

Question / Statement: The "Shoulder" serves as an emergency lane for broken-down vehicles.
Explanation: It is the strip alongside the carriageway.

Question / Statement: CBR (California Bearing Ratio) test is done on bitumen.
Explanation: CBR is done on Sub-grade soil to test its strength.

Question / Statement: Stopping Sight Distance (SSD) is always greater than Overtaking Sight Distance (OSD).
Explanation: OSD is always greater than SSD because you need more space to pass.

Question / Statement: "Warning Signs" on roads are usually triangular in shape.
Explanation: Circular are mandatory, Rectangular are informatory.

Question / Statement: Traffic volume is measured in PCU (Passenger Car Units).
Explanation: PCU converts different vehicle types into a standard unit.

Question / Statement: Expansion joints are required in Flexible Pavements.
Explanation: They are required in Rigid (Concrete) pavements due to thermal expansion.

Question / Statement: A "Gradient" of 1 in 20 is steeper than 1 in 50.
Explanation: 1 vertical unit in 20 horizontal is steeper than 1 in 50.
